test_patch:
diff --git a/test/sql/catalog/test_set_search_path.test b/test/sql/catalog/test_set_search_path.test
index 52f07cd68180..d82a8782d3e7 100644
--- a/test/sql/catalog/test_set_search_path.test
+++ b/test/sql/catalog/test_set_search_path.test
@@ -83,9 +83,9 @@ SELECT MAIN.CURRENT_SETTING('search_path');
 test,test2
 
 query I
-SELECT MAIN.CURRENT_SETTING('schema');
+SELECT MAIN.CURRENT_SCHEMAS(false);
 ----
-test,test2
+[test, test2]
 
 statement ok
 SET SCHEMA = 'test';
@@ -96,7 +96,7 @@ SELECT MAIN.CURRENT_SETTING('search_path');
 test
 
 query I
-SELECT MAIN.CURRENT_SETTING('schema');
+SELECT MAIN.CURRENT_SCHEMA();
 ----
 test
 
diff --git a/test/sql/settings/drop_set_schema.test b/test/sql/settings/drop_set_schema.test
new file mode 100644
index 000000000000..db25e55e102b
--- /dev/null
+++ b/test/sql/settings/drop_set_schema.test
@@ -0,0 +1,97 @@
+# name: test/sql/settings/drop_set_schema.test
+# group: [settings]
+
+# 'db2' is an in-memory database, which no longer exists after restarting
+# So we have to exclude this test from Force Restart runs
+require skip_reload
+
+statement ok
+pragma enable_verification;
+
+# Create a new schema
+statement ok
+create schema my_schema;
+
+# Verify that 'main' is the default
+query I
+select current_schema();
+----
+main
+
+# Set it as the default schema
+statement ok
+SET schema='my_schema';
+
+# Verify that it changed
+query I
+select current_schema();
+----
+my_schema
+
+# Then drop it
+statement ok
+drop schema my_schema;
+
+# The 'current_schema' setting should be reset to the default ('main')
+query I
+select current_schema();
+----
+main
+
+# Create two new schemas
+
+statement ok
+create schema schema1;
+
+statement ok
+create schema schema2;
+
+# Set the current schema to 'schema1'
+statement ok
+set schema='schema1';
+
+query I
+select current_schema();
+----
+schema1
+
+# Then drop 'schema2'
+statement ok
+drop schema schema2;
+
+# The current schema should be unaffected
+query I
+select current_schema();
+----
+schema1
+
+# Create a new in memory db
+statement ok
+ATTACH ':memory:' as db2;
+
+# Create an identically named schema
+statement ok
+create schema db2.schema1;
+
+# USE would change the current_schema, so we can't use that
+#statement ok
+#USE db2;
+
+# Drop this schema
+statement ok
+drop schema db2.schema1;
+
+# The current schema should again be unaltered
+query I
+select current_schema();
+----
+schema1
+
+# Only when we drop the other 'schema1' should it be altered again
+statement ok
+drop schema schema1;
+
+query I
+select current_schema();
+----
+main
problem_statement:
DROP SCHEMA does not update the current schema configuration setting. 
### What happens?

If you set the current schema and then drop that schema, the current schema setting retains its value.

### To Reproduce

```
create schema my_schema;

SET schema='my_schema';

drop schema my_schema;

select current_schema();

┌──────────────────┐
│ current_schema() │
│     varchar      │
├──────────────────┤
│ my_schema        │
└──────────────────┘
create table t ( id int);

Error: Catalog Error: Schema with name my_schema does not exist!

select version();
┌───────────┐
│ version() │
│  varchar  │
├───────────┤
│ v0.6.1    │
└───────────┘
```

### OS:

Windows 10 Pro

### DuckDB Version:

0.61

### DuckDB Client:

CLI/WASM

### Full Name:

Roland Bouman

### Affiliation:

EPAM

### Have you tried this on the latest `master` branch?

- [X] I agree

### Have you tried the steps to reproduce? Do they include all relevant data and configuration? Does the issue you report still appear there?

- [X] I agree
hints_text:
The reason why I believe this is a bug is that you cannot modify the schema configuration to a schema that does not exist:

```
D set schema='bla';
Error: Catalog Error: SET schema: No schema named bla found.
```

Against that background it seems inconsistent that drop schema could get you into that state.
Thanks for the report!
What do you think the desired behavior should be?
1. Don't allow dropping of a schema set as the default schema
2. Change the default schema back to `main` when the dropped schema was the default schema
I think it should be 2. 

1 initially seems tempting, but then it seems the behavior should be different depending on whether the CASCADE option was specified, as in, without CASCADE, the DROP SCHEMA statement would be expected to fail, but with CASCADE one would expect the action to be forced anyway, in which case the problem of what the default schema should become after the DROP would still need to be solved.
